original_data.question: A 32-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of weight loss, night sweats, and productive cough. Auscultation of the lungs shows coarse crackles at the right upper posterior field. An x-ray of the chest shows an opacity in the right upper lobe. Sputum analysis shows acid-fast bacilli. A small amount of tuberculin fluid is injected into the subcutaneous tissue on the left forearm. Examination of the injected area 48 hours later shows no induration or erythema. Impairment of which of the following processes is the most likely cause of the negative tuberculin skin test seen in this patient?

options.A: Interaction of B7 and CD28 ligands

model_response:
The negative tuberculin skin test in this HIV-infected patient indicates a poor T-cell response to antigen. The interaction of B7 and CD28 ligands is required for full T-cell activation. Opsonization by complement proteins occurs in the classic pathway and is not required for T-cell activation. Interleukin-4 is required for the development of Th2 cells, which are involved in allergic and other immune responses, but not for T-cell activation. Generation of reactive oxygen species is a mechanism used by many cells to kill microorganisms. The absence of interleukin-12 would impair the development of a Th1 cell response, not a T-cell response.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

Human immunodeficiency virus. A non-taxonomic and historical term referring to any of two species, specifically HIV-1 and/or HIV-2. Prior to 1986, this was called human T-lymphotropic virus type III/lymphadenopathy-associated virus (HTLV-III/LAV). From 1986-1990, it was an official species called HIV. Since 1991, HIV was no longer considered an official species name; the two species were designated HIV-1 and HIV-2.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
Perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
A cough accompanied by expectorated secretions.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Either of the pair of organs occupying the cavity of the thorax that effect the aeration of the blood.
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
The quality of being opaque to a degree; the degree to which something reduces the passage of light.
The lobe of the right lung, situated above the horizontal fissure, which includes the apex.

Examination and interpretation; the process of identifying an issue to be understood and addressed, modelling the issue, investigating the model results, interpreting the results, and possibly making a recommendation. The concept also refers to the examination and study of a whole in terms of the parts composing it.
a kind of rod-shaped bacteria

A protein extracted from boiled culture of tubercle bacilli (MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS). It is used in the tuberculin skin test (TUBERCULIN TEST) for the diagnosis of tuberculosis infection in asymptomatic persons.

Adipose tissue located under the dermis. It binds underlying structures with the skin. The subcutis is important in the regulation of temperature of the skin itself and the body. The size of this layer varies throughout the body and from person to person.
Redness of the skin produced by congestion of the capillaries. This condition may result from a variety of disease processes.
Loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, or anatomic structure or function.
Conceptual functions or thinking in all its forms.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]

One of several skin tests to determine past or present tuberculosis infection. A purified protein derivative of the tubercle bacilli, called tuberculin, is introduced into the skin by scratch, puncture, or interdermal injection.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
